issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) requires a class named Farm (with attribute 'animals' and methods addAnimal, singFarmSong, feedAllAnimals). The template file template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java instead declares a class named AnimalFarm. This name/type mismatch between the expected type 'Farm' (problem statement) and the class provided in the template will confuse students and prevent them from compiling or following the UML. The solution repository implements a class named Farm, showing the intended name.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the class in template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java from AnimalFarm to Farm and ensure the file and class name match the UML and references in Main. The Farm class signature and public API should match the UML (attribute 'animals' of type List<Animal>, methods addAnimal(Animal), feedAllAnimals(), singFarmSong()).

issues.description: The template file template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java contains internally inconsistent and syntactically invalid code: a method body contains another package declaration and a duplicate class declaration (the file shows 'public class AnimalFarm' and then inside singFarmSong() the file repeats 'package de.tum.cit.ase;' and re-declares 'public class AnimalFarm'). This self-contradiction and invalid structure will prevent the project from compiling and blocks students from using the template as a starting point to implement the intended design.
issues.suggested_fix: Replace the contents of template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java with a clean stub matching the exercise intent (a public class Farm in package de.tum.cit.ase). Remove the duplicated package declaration and nested class/code. Provide correct class skeleton (constructor initializing animals list, getter/setter for animals, addAnimal, feedAllAnimals, singFarmSong and a private helper singFarmSongVerse) so students can compile the project and implement the missing animal/interface classes per the UML.

issues.description: The problem statement and solution expect a class named 'Farm' (the UML and tasks explicitly refer to implementing a Farm class). The template file src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java instead declares a public class named 'AnimalFarm'. This naming mismatch (filename Farm.java vs. public class AnimalFarm) breaks the direct mapping from the exercise description to the starter code, will confuse students about which class to implement, and will cause compilation/expectation errors when students try to follow the instructions.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the public class in template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java from 'AnimalFarm' to 'Farm' so the public class name matches the filename and the problem statement. Alternatively (less recommended), rename the file to AnimalFarm.java and update the problem statement and solution to use 'AnimalFarm' consistently — but the simplest fix is to change the template class name to 'Farm' to align with the exercise description and the solution.
